With only one level of Monk, your unarmed strike damage would be 1d6. The same exact damage as a single Kama. Your attack progression is not any different. The only bonus to going unarmed vs using a Kama are the unarmed specific gloves. You cannot use GMW or Darkfire on unarmed because you do not have a weapon to cast them on. I cannot think of a Cleric/monk build that would be better off with unarmed strike.. but I might be missing something. You don't have spell slots or even spell levels to use extend until you get more Cleric levels anyway.

No, they weren't taken at random, they were taken to be able to disable and set traps UP TO A CERTAIN POINT. You need to know how traps work in order to look at these builds with a critical eye, lest you fall under the very wrong impression that these great builders didn't know what they were doing. LOL

General rule is, if your server has epic traps and you have enough skill points, go for them. If not, then you need to pick how far you wanna go:

15 RANKS in Set Traps will allow you to set all deadly traps except two, can't remember which ones. You can have 13 RANKS if you have more than 5 RANKS in Disable traps because of the synergy bonus.

25 RANKS of Set Traps (23 if you have Disable Traps synergy bonus) will allow you to set all Deadly traps, and 45 (43 with bonus) Modified Ranks will allow you to set Epic ones.

But in order to set them, you need to be able to get them, so it's not just Set Traps you need to worry about. Disable Traps also needs to be taken heavily so you can recover the traps and use them yourself, and Search so you can find them in the first place, so it's a heavy skill point investment. If you don't have the skill points, you need to make cuts and let go of epic traps, then the two deadly ones with the higher DCs and then if you still can't afford them, just drop the skill altogether.

If you want ED earlier than level 39, you'd be best off changing your distribution to Cleric 24/Rogue 15/Monk 1. All attacks in a flurry have SA damage added to them if SA goes off.

I'm sure there are some other negatives to losing 2 levels of cleric besides what I listed, but I can't think of anything else. In my mind, the tradeoff is not that extreme and might almost be a wash, if not slightly on the side of Rogue 15, depending on playstyle.

Max may still prefer his Cleric 26/Rogue 13 version for max level 40 power, but you aren't giving up that much power for a lot of playability. I also think that Crippling strike, more skill points, and 1d6 of extra SA is more powerful than 1 Lvl 3 spell, 1 Lvl 7 spell (with capped Wis), 1 AC, and 1 will. So maybe Max will even agree that this is a good balance between level 40 power and playability throughout. The dispellabilty bothers me, but it's not a huge risk given the gains.
I would definitely agree, as I was the one to suggest this tweak as exactly that: a balance between playability and level 40 power. It's less gimped than Kail's 25 14 1 spread or your suggested 24 15 1, as it doesn't give up something for playability, just trades it for something else.

However, this is my reasoning here: With ED at 39, I get much earlier undispellability, which is IMO more important to this build than earlier ED. The build as is with earlier ED will only be 5% dispellable at level 40, and the way he took the levels, will be VERY VULNERABLE to dispel pretty much till late 30s. Also, the stat points are so crunched up that he's unable to use lvl 7 and 8 spells till very late in the build, which is IMO not cost effective to get ED earlier. I prefer to get ED as icing to the cake in an already VERY HIGH AC build and have my full clericalness at my disposal much earlier. However, each to their own.

Regardless, it's nice to see your growth in such a short time to a point where you're actually giving good suggestions and picking up very specific things like the DEX for WIS exchange in this build once the requirements for ED are fulfilled. Congrats!

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Let's count all the archery related cleric buffs. Bless, Aid, Prayer, Battletide, Divine favor and Divine power. Cat's and Bull's are also available to arcane characters, so I will not count them in here.
For a level 15 cleric Bless, Aid, Prayer and Battletide together add +5 AB and +3 damage. DF adds +5 AB and +5 damage. DP adds +5 or thereabout AB, depending on BAB, and can add to mighty damage if base strength is lower than 18. It also adds an extra attack.
All in all we talk about a temporary gain of about +15 to AB and +8 damage (+added mighty from DP)
Some of these spells are turn/level, some are rounds/level. DF lasts 1 turn (2 extended). None of the spells will add to DR penetration.
Rogue can add to damage with sneak attacks.
You are also free to pick other races than elf/half-elf, and can use any ranged weapon. Xp penalty can soon become a problem.
You can aim at maxing wisdom for Zen archery with great wisdom as epic cleric bonus feat. Of course you will not get those bonus feats if cleric stops at 15.
With BAB 25, WF, EWF, EP and wis 30 we talk about a naked AB of +39. If on the other hand wis can be maxed to 38, we talk about AB +43. Add +1 if small size and another +1 if a halfling with a sling or thrown weapon.
An elf bard/x/AA29 can have a BAB 29 with 4 attacks, a dexterity of 40 and an Enchant Arrow bonus of +15, giving a naked AB of + 59 and a damage bonus of 15 before you start counting mighty or buffs. Enchant Arrow alone can pierce DR, even with a mundane bow.
A fully buffed lvl 40 cleric can in some ways compete with an unbuffed AA and is all in all not a shabby archer build with many buffing abilities. But Cleric is then near the AB cap. Once you start adding spells, bard song and items, and count mighty, the AA can go much higher.
